Title: Outsourcing of Risk - Assurance Review 2020/21 - IT Patching and Maintenance
Description:
NS&I has an outsourced customer servicing model which, in addition, provides IT and infrastructure services. These services are provided to NS&I by Atos. As part of this agreement Atos are responsible for maintaining and keeping up to date the servers and software used by both their own sales processing and customer servicing teams, and by NS&I staff.

IT patching is split into two main areas:

•	Patching of the server estate used to service operations, overseen by NS&I's IS and Information Assurance team;
•	Patching of security vulnerability overseen by the IT Security team.

NS&I wishes to appoint a suitable firm to conduct a review of Atos's patch management. The scope of this review will focus on the management of server estate patching and will exclude security vulnerabilities.

Title: HMRC Making Tax Digital Compliance
Description: The council is required to comply with HMRC's upcoming Making Tax Digital (MTD) policy which is set to change the way VAT returns are kept and submitted. All businesses registered for VAT with a taxable turnover above the VAT registration threshold (£85,000) must keep digital business records and send all VAT returns to HMRC using MTD compatible software. Seven essential criteria were outlined which included a full readiness review, software that meets the MTD compliance requirements, the creation of an interface and/or digital links between the council's existing software and the LA schools systems, software capable of managing the council's partial exemption calculations, a supplier with tax expertise, a supplier committed to maintain their solution in the event of any changes in legislation and a supplier who would offer ongoing post-implementation support.

Title: CDIO Assurance Framework
Description:
HMRC Control Framework Project needs to produce a CDIO Control Framework, including education for process owners in the assessment of risk and the identification of appropriate and proportionate controls.  This is combined with the CDIO Future Mode of Operation and changing capability requirements for CDIO processes.

The resource required will: 
•	Inform the approach and development of a CDIO Control Framework bringing industry knowledge and experience to the build of a project plan that ensures an appropriate control framework and control objectives for CDIO.
•	Provide assurance expertise, IT knowledge of the standards and frameworks underpinning COBIT 5 and access to subject matter experts to support reviews focused on the risks associated with CDIO Future Mode of Operation. 
•	Continue to ensure skills transfer to the CDIO team enhancing the team's theoretical learning and delivering practical methodology for CDIO.

Title: Calculating the Cumulative Administrative Burden of Energy and Climate Change Reporting Requirements on UK
Description:
The overall aim of this work is twofold. First is to calculate the cumulative administrative burden of the carbon reduction policies outlined in Table 1 on UK businesses. Second is to examine the business energy and climate change reporting landscape legislation holistically to understand the overlapping burden of the several different schemes, and provide recommendations on how processes could be improved and simplified.
Possible examples of simplification include making the following changes across the schemes: removing possible duplication of effort, aligning reporting periods, standardising reporting units, standardisation of documentation submissions and verification requirements and the sharing of data, so business only has to submit information once, and not each time per differing scheme.

Title: DFID 6624 Management of the Flexible Facility for the Private Sector Development Programme – Democratic Republic of Congo
Description:
Actual CPV code 75211200

The Flexible Facility Service Provider will, on an as-needed basis, design and implement business environment, access to finance and anti-corruption interventions in order to contribute to private sector development and poverty alleviation in DRC. This work will commence with a programme of support to the Government of DRC for the implementation of OHADA law, practices and institutions. Subsequent interventions will be designated by DFID DRC via the mechanisms specified in section 4 below.
The Flexible Facility Service Provider will contribute to the achievement of outcome indicator 1 of the log frame for DFID DRC’s Private Sector Development Programme: to support DRC to reduce its distance to the frontier of the World Bank Doing Business Indicators from 35 to 52.  Detailed, intervention-specific log frames for the Flexible Facility Service Provider will be developed during the inception phase of each intervention and agreed by DFID DRC as specified in section 5 below. 
The expected duration of the Flexible Facility is five years with an approximate budget of £35 million. This budget includes the service provider’s management costs as well as the design and implementation costs of any interventions. Note that, given the nature of this programme, expenditure will proceed incrementally up to this budget ceiling depending on the emergence of intervention opportunities and progress against results and value for money metrics. If suitable opportunities do not arise, or insufficient progress is made, the budget and duration of the facility will be reduced. Conversely, there is scope to increase this budget if sufficient interventions are identified and if on-going monitoring, evaluation, and analysis suggest that such a rebalancing would be warranted.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Price Waterhouse Coopers LLP|7 More London Riverside|||No|No]

Title: Leadership and Behavioural Development Framework
Description: The transformation plan consists of seven work streams: Supply Chain, Projects, Value streams, Enterprise Management, Technology and Innovation, Safety and Security, and Leadership and People. One of the ways Sellafield Ltd has identified to support this transformation is by developing the leadership, culture, values and behaviours of a high-performance company, and responding to the resource and capability needs created by mission change and efficiency. We aim to do this through the creation and embedding of a high-performance culture through a leadership development framework, coaching at all levels and more visible talent pipelines.
Additional Text:
The intent of this Notice is to understand if the supply chain would find it beneficial to attend a supplier briefing on the 'Leadership and Behavioural Development Framework' specification, with supplementary information on the transformation programme which this procurement will be supporting. If sufficient interest is generated a session will be arranged. At this stage it is envisaged that representatives from the Human Resources Department, EHS&Q and Commercial would be available to explain the requirements and offer the opportunity for questions and discussion.  

This would take place on the 23rd January at 10.30 at the Rheged Conference Centre in Penrith. It is expected that this will run for 2 hours.

This will be limited to 2 delegates per company.

Please notify Sharon Pearson at Sharon.pearson@sellafieldsites.com if you would like to attend with details of the attendees and Company representing.  Could you please respond by the 12th January 2018.

Full address of the conference facility: Rheged, Redhills, Penrith, Cumbria, CA11 ODQ.

The nearest train station is Penrith and the venue is a 2 mile drive from the station. There is a taxi rank at the station.
